data.body: Can you please provide a jsfiddle?

TextureLoader uses ImageLoader that creates the image using:

``` javascript
var image = document.createElement( 'img' );
```

Those elements doesn't support `progress` events, see http://www.w3schools.com/jsref/dom_obj_event.asp

Should textures be loaded with (our old friend) `XMLHttpRequest` instead? :wink:
Hmm... and convert to dataurl?
What I did in #7749 :)
Can someone write workaround here?
ha wait, I did not put [progress listener](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest/Using_XMLHttpRequest#Monitoring_progress) there XD
@kschzt did you have any luck with this?

@mrdoob yes - we are using our own Image loader for the time being:

https://github.com/vizorvr/vizor/blob/develop/browser/scripts/loaders/imageLoader.js#L24

and our TextureLoader just: https://github.com/vizorvr/vizor/blob/develop/browser/scripts/loaders/textureLoader.js#L10-L14

More experimentation has shown that the time spent parsing the Arraybuffer into a usable Image is around 500ms for a 60mb stereo cubemap texture. But for Vizor.io, the benefit of being able to wait and show progress to the user before autoplaying really trumps everything :)

> More experimentation has shown that the time spent parsing the Arraybuffer into a usable Image is around 500ms for a 60mb stereo cubemap texture.

How many ms does the browser take?
That is browser time. https://github.com/vizorvr/vizor/blob/develop/browser/scripts/loaders/imageLoader.js#L18-L26 is the timer
I know I know. I meant... in comparison `new Image()`.
0? by the time image.onload is called, the image is ready.

Well, imagine we change `ImageLoader` so it uses this approach. I'm wondering if the browser does something internally when using `Image` that it's faster.

Otherwise, a PR would be more than welcome! 😊
it may be faster or not, but unlike xhr thing it does not block js thread. maybe it should use xhr only if there are any progress listeners?

Hello, I very much appreciate what  you have done in creating D3 (whoops I mean Three.js - left for continuity) and would love to see this resolved to a working implementation described in the official documentation.
@mpaccione I think you got the wrong project: https://github.com/mbostock/d3

Ah so much on my mind, I meant Three.js. I'm using Three.js and have an issue where sometimes the webserver doesn't load serve the textures needed and the loader progress and error callback would  be most useful....typos sheesh i need more coffee...at least there was a three in it hehe.
@mpaccione Is that on Chrome 50? If so... #8670
@mpaccione also error handler should be called, this issue was about progress only

@mrdoob Ah Yes, 8670 would explain the reason why I put in a texture loader progress in the first place. I was expecting the issue to trigger the error handler. It appears it doesn't as makc says the error handler works. I look forward to the texture loader progress event being worked out as it will be relevant in my data visualization. Thank you for developing this excellent technology, it has changed my technical interests for sure.

> I want to create a TextureLoader instance

no, what you want is to create AjaxTextureLoader instance. no further voodoo is required.

oh, the only difference I see is that AjaxTextureLoader's load() won't return the texture immediately, you will have to pick it up from onLoad

> what do you mean when you say "AjaxTextureLoader's load() won't return the texture immediately, you will have to pick it up from onLoad"

I mean it literally. TextureLoader returns texture, and then sends it to you again as an argument to onLoad, iirc. AjaxTextureLoader above only does 2nd half, because it is lazy and does not create the texture itself.

> Is that the problem ?

Not really.

> When I use it I got this result :
> My material.map : undefined

Quite possible. So just set material.map to new THREE.Texture, and then later set it again to whatever you receive in onLoad.

> My onProgress callback : is executed twice.

More than 0 then, yay!

> I do not understand where is the problem here.

Me neither.
[Here is a fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/f2Lommf5/585/) for you, @Claod44 - if this does not help, I give up 😘
